a) The NCCET and JCET separate operations should be concluded. It
is believed that the great bulk of the first wave of educational
stations will by then be on the air. The services needed can
more efficiently be performed by the NAEB (an Association) and
a Center (TV Network) than by having other groups perpetuate
themselves in duplicated efforts.
b) That the JCET remain as the NAEB Advisory Committee to insure
continuity and completion of present efforts.
c) That the JCET, in skeleton^staff form, become the NAEB Washington
(East Coast) office headed by an NAEB Associate Director, possibly
the present Director or other staff member of the JCET.
d) That the NCCET, essentially a publicity and public-relations
organization, become the center of a newly-created, urgently
needed, coordinated publication. This might, but probably would
not be, an NAEB-sponsored activity. In any case the NAEB would
support and share in its direction.
e) That an endowment or other long-term system of support be set up
to insure that all essential functions of all these organizations,
with the Center, be insured of adequate tenure to make sure that an
economically based association system will gradually develop which
will have the possibility of survival even when and as all found¬
ation funds are withdrawn. This period of support should probably
be not less than ten nor more than twenty years. This will in¬
volve basic discussions as suggested by the financial discussion,
(which is yet to come).
